Module contents#

Core package for selective inference.

exception sicore.InfiniteLoopError#

Bases: Exception

class sicore.NaiveInferenceChi(data: ndarray, var: float | ndarray | csr_array, P: ndarray | csr_array, use_sparse: bool = False, use_tf: bool = False, use_torch: bool = False)#

Bases: InferenceChi

Naive inference for a test statistic which follows chi squared distribution under null.

Parameters:

  • data (np.ndarray, tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor) â€“ Observation data in 1-D array. When given as a tensor, activate the corresponding option.

  • var (float, np.ndarray, tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor, sparse.csr_array) â€“ Value of known variance covariance. Assuming that the shape of the input is a scalar or 1-D array or 2-D array, the variance-covariance matrix Cov is interpreted as follows. When the input is a scalar, Cov = input * Identity. When the input is a 1-D array, Cov = diag(input). When the input is a 2-D array, Cov = input. Also, activate the option, when given as a sparse array.

  • P (np.ndarray, tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor, sparse.csr_array) â€“ Projection matrix in 2-D array. When given as a tensor or a sparse array, activate the corresponding option.

  • use_sparse (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use sparse matrix or not. Defaults to False.

  • use_tf (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use tensorflow or not. Defaults to False.

  • use_torch (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use pytorch or not. Defaults to False.

inference(alternative: str = 'less')#

Perform naive statistical inference.

Parameters:

alternative (str, optional) â€“ â€˜two-sidedâ€™ for two-tailed test, â€˜lessâ€™ for right-tailed test, â€˜greaterâ€™ for left-tailed test. Defaults to â€˜lessâ€™.

Returns:

p-value

Return type:

float

class sicore.NaiveInferenceNorm(data: ndarray, var: float | ndarray | csr_array, eta: ndarray, use_sparse: bool = False, use_tf: bool = False, use_torch: bool = False)#

Bases: InferenceNorm

Naive inference for a test statistic which follows normal distribution under null.

Parameters:

  • data (np.ndarray, List[float], tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor) â€“ Observation data in 1-D array. When given as a tensor, activate the corresponding option.

  • var (float, np.ndarray, tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor, sparse.csr_array) â€“ Value of known variance covariance. Assuming that the shape of the input is a scalar or 1-D array or 2-D array, the variance-covariance matrix Cov is interpreted as follows. When the input is a scalar, Cov = input * Identity. When the input is a 1-D array, Cov = diag(input). When the input is a 2-D array, Cov = input. Also, activate the option, when given as a sparse array.

  • eta (np.ndarray, List[float], tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor) â€“ Contrast vector in 1-D array. When given as a tensor, activate the corresponding option.

  • use_sparse (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use sparse array or not. Defaults to False.

  • use_tf (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use tensorflow or not. Defaults to False.

  • use_torch (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use pytorch or not. Defaults to False.

inference(alternative: str = 'two-sided', popmean: float = 0)#

Perform naive statistical inference.

Parameters:

  • alternative (str, optional) â€“ â€˜two-sidedâ€™ for two-tailed test, â€˜lessâ€™ for right-tailed test, â€˜greaterâ€™ for left-tailed test. Defaults to â€˜two-sidedâ€™.

  • popmean (float, optional) â€“ Population mean of the test statistic under null hypothesis. Defaults to 0.

Returns:

p-value

Return type:

float

class sicore.OneVec(length)#

Bases: object

Vector whose elements from position i to j are set to 1, and 0 otherwise.

Parameters:

length (int) â€“ Dimension of the vector.

get(i, j=None)#

Get the vector.

Parameters:

  • i (int) â€“ Start index of 1 (1<=i<=`length`).

  • j (int, optional) â€“ End index of 1 (1<=j<=`length`). If None, it returns a vector whose `i`th element is set to 1, and 0 otherwise. Defaults toNone.

Returns:

one-zero vector

Return type:

np.ndarray

class sicore.SelectiveInferenceChi(data: ndarray, var: float | ndarray | csr_array, P: ndarray | csr_array, use_sparse: bool = False, use_tf: bool = False, use_torch: bool = False)#

Bases: InferenceChi

Selective inference for a test statistic which follows chi squared distribution under null.

Parameters:

  • data (np.ndarray, tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor) â€“ Observation data in 1-D array. When given as a tensor, activate the corresponding option.

  • var (float, np.ndarray, tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor, sparse.csr_array) â€“ Value of known variance covariance. Assuming that the shape of the input is a scalar or 1-D array or 2-D array, the variance-covariance matrix Cov is interpreted as follows. When the input is a scalar, Cov = input * Identity. When the input is a 1-D array, Cov = diag(input). When the input is a 2-D array, Cov = input. Also, activate the option, when given as a sparse array.

  • P (np.ndarray, tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor, sparse.csr_array) â€“ Projection matrix in 2-D array. When given as a tensor or a sparse array, activate the corresponding option.

  • use_sparse (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use sparse matrix or not. Defaults to False.

  • use_tf (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use tensorflow or not. Defaults to False.

  • use_torch (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use pytorch or not. Defaults to False.

inference(algorithm: Callable[[ndarray, ndarray, float], tuple[list[list[float]], Any]], model_selector: Callable[[Any], bool], significance_level: float = 0.05, precision: float = 0.001, termination_criterion: str = 'precision', search_strategy: str = 'pi3', step: float = 1e-10, max_iter: int = 1000000.0, over_conditioning: bool = False, exhaustive: bool = False, max_tail: float = 1000.0, alternative: str = 'abs', retain_observed_model: bool = False, retain_mappings: bool = False, tol: float = 1e-10, dps: int | str = 'auto', max_dps: int = 5000, out_log: str = 'test_log.log') → SelectiveInferenceResult#

Perform Selective Inference.

Parameters:

  • algorithm (Callable[[np.ndarray, np.ndarray, float], Tuple[List[List[float]], Any]]) â€“ Callable function which takes two vectors (a, b) and a scalar z that can satisfy data = a + b * z as argument, and returns the obtained model (Any) and the intervals (np.ndarray) where it is obtained. A closure function might be helpful to implement this.

  • model_selector (Callable[[Any], bool]) â€“ Callable function which takes a obtained model (any) as single argument, and returns True if the model is observed one, and False otherwise.

  • significance_level (float, optional) â€“ Significance level for the test. Defaults to 0.05.

  • precision (float, optional) â€“ Precision required to compute p-value. Defaults to 0.001.

  • termination_criterion (str, optional) â€“ Specifies the termination criterion used to perform parametric selective inference. This option is ignored when the over_conditioning or exhaustive is activated. â€˜precisionâ€™ for computing p-value with precision. â€˜decisionâ€™ for making decision whether or not to reject at significance_level. Defaults to â€˜precisionâ€™.

  • search_strategy (str, optional) â€“ Specifies the search strategy used to perform parametric selective inference. â€˜pi1â€™ focuses on the integral on truncated intervals. â€˜pi2â€™ focuses on the integral on searched intervals. â€˜pi3â€™ focuses on the both of integrals. Defaults to â€˜pi3â€™.

  • step (float, optional) â€“ Step width for parametric search. Defaults to 1e-10.

  • max_iter (int, optional) â€“ Maximum number of times to perform parametric search. If this value is exceeded, the loop is considered to be infinite. Defaults to 1e6.

  • over_conditioning (bool, optional) â€“ Over conditioning inference. Defaults to False.

  • exhaustive (bool, optional) â€“ Exhaustive search of the range specified by max_tail. Defaults to False.

  • max_tail (float, optional) â€“ Specifies the range to be searched when exhaustive is activated. Defaults to 1e3.

  • alternative (str, optional) â€“ â€˜absâ€™ for two-tailed test of the absolute value of test statistic. â€˜two-sidedâ€™ for two-tailed test. â€˜lessâ€™ for right-tailed test. â€˜greaterâ€™ for left-tailed test. Defaults to â€˜absâ€™.

  • retain_observed_model (bool, optional) â€“ Whether retain observed model as returns or not. Defaults to False.

  • retain_mappings (bool, optional) â€“ Whether retain mappings as returns or not. Defaults to False.

  • tol (float, optional) â€“ Tolerance error parameter for intervals. Defaults to 1e-10.

  • dps (int | str, optional) â€“ dps value for mpmath. Set â€˜autoâ€™ to select dps automatically. Defaults to â€˜autoâ€™.

  • max_dps (int, optional) â€“ Maximum dps value for mpmath. This option is valid when dps is set to â€˜autoâ€™. Defaults to 5000.

  • out_log (str, optional) â€“ Name for log file of mpmath. Defaults to â€˜test_log.logâ€™.

Raises:

Exception â€“ When over_conditioning and exhaustive are activated simultaneously

Returns:

SelectiveInferenceResult

class sicore.SelectiveInferenceNorm(data: ndarray, var: float | ndarray | csr_array, eta: ndarray, use_sparse: bool = False, use_tf: bool = False, use_torch: bool = False)#

Bases: InferenceNorm

Selective inference for a test statistic which follows normal distribution under null.

Parameters:

  • data (np.ndarray, List[float], tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor) â€“ Observation data in 1-D array. When given as a tensor, activate the corresponding option.

  • var (float, np.ndarray, tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor, sparse.csr_array) â€“ Value of known variance covariance. Assuming that the shape of the input is a scalar or 1-D array or 2-D array, the variance-covariance matrix Cov is interpreted as follows. When the input is a scalar, Cov = input * Identity. When the input is a 1-D array, Cov = diag(input). When the input is a 2-D array, Cov = input. Also, activate the option, when given as a sparse array.

  • eta (np.ndarray, List[float], tf.Tensor, torch.Tensor) â€“ Contrast vector in 1-D array. When given as a tensor, activate the corresponding option.

  • use_sparse (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use sparse array or not. Defaults to False.

  • use_tf (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use tensorflow or not. Defaults to False.

  • use_torch (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use pytorch or not. Defaults to False.

inference(algorithm: Callable[[ndarray, ndarray, float], tuple[list[list[float]], Any]], model_selector: Callable[[Any], bool], significance_level: float = 0.05, precision: float = 0.001, termination_criterion: str = 'precision', search_strategy: str = 'pi3', step: float = 1e-10, max_iter: int = 1000000.0, over_conditioning: bool = False, exhaustive: bool = False, max_tail: float = 1000.0, alternative: str = 'abs', retain_observed_model: bool = False, retain_mappings: bool = False, tol: float = 1e-10, dps: int | str = 'auto', max_dps: int = 5000, out_log: str = 'test_log.log') → SelectiveInferenceResult#

Perform Selective Inference.

Parameters:

  • algorithm (Callable[[np.ndarray, np.ndarray, float], Tuple[List[List[float]], Any]]) â€“ Callable function which takes two vectors (a, b) and a scalar z that can satisfy data = a + b * z as argument, and returns the obtained model (Any) and the intervals (np.ndarray) where it is obtained. A closure function might be helpful to implement this.

  • model_selector (Callable[[Any], bool]) â€“ Callable function which takes a obtained model (any) as single argument, and returns True if the model is observed one, and False otherwise.

  • significance_level (float, optional) â€“ Significance level for the test. Defaults to 0.05.

  • precision (float, optional) â€“ Precision required to compute p-value. Defaults to 0.001.

  • termination_criterion (str, optional) â€“ Specifies the termination criterion used to perform parametric selective inference. This option is ignored when the over_conditioning or exhaustive is activated. â€˜precisionâ€™ for computing p-value with precision. â€˜decisionâ€™ for making decision whether or not to reject at significance_level. Defaults to â€˜precisionâ€™.

  • search_strategy (str, optional) â€“ Specifies the search strategy used to perform parametric selective inference. â€˜pi1â€™ focuses on the integral on truncated intervals. â€˜pi2â€™ focuses on the integral on searched intervals. â€˜pi3â€™ focuses on the both of integrals. Defaults to â€˜pi3â€™.

  • step (float, optional) â€“ Step width for parametric search. Defaults to 1e-10.

  • max_iter (int, optional) â€“ Maximum number of times to perform parametric search. If this value is exceeded, the loop is considered to be infinite. Defaults to 1e6.

  • over_conditioning (bool, optional) â€“ Over conditioning inference. Defaults to False.

  • exhaustive (bool, optional) â€“ Exhaustive search of the range specified by max_tail. Defaults to False.

  • max_tail (float, optional) â€“ Specifies the range to be searched when exhaustive is activated. Defaults to 1e3.

  • alternative (str, optional) â€“ â€˜absâ€™ for two-tailed test of the absolute value of test statistic. â€˜two-sidedâ€™ for two-tailed test. â€˜lessâ€™ for right-tailed test. â€˜greaterâ€™ for left-tailed test. Defaults to â€˜absâ€™.

  • retain_observed_model (bool, optional) â€“ Whether retain observed model as returns or not. Defaults to False.

  • retain_mappings (bool, optional) â€“ Whether retain mappings as returns or not. Defaults to False.

  • tol (float, optional) â€“ Tolerance error parameter for intervals. Defaults to 1e-10.

  • dps (int | str, optional) â€“ dps value for mpmath. Set â€˜autoâ€™ to select dps automatically. Defaults to â€˜autoâ€™.

  • max_dps (int, optional) â€“ Maximum dps value for mpmath. This option is valid when dps is set to â€˜autoâ€™. Defaults to 5000.

  • out_log (str, optional) â€“ Name for log file of mpmath. Defaults to â€˜test_log.logâ€™.

Raises:

Exception â€“ When over_conditioning and exhaustive are activated simultaneously

Returns:

SelectiveInferenceResult

class sicore.SelectiveInferenceResult(stat: float, alpha: float, p_value: float, inf_p: float, sup_p: float, reject_or_not: bool, truncated_intervals: list[list[float]], search_count: int, detect_count: int, selected_model: Any | None, mappings: dict[tuple[float, float], Any] | None)#

Bases: object

This class contains the results of selective inference.

stat#

Observed value of test statistic.

Type:

float

alpha#

Significance level.

Type:

float

p_value#

p-value from test performed.

Type:

float

inf_p#

Lower bound of p-value.

Type:

float

sup_p#

Upper bound of p-value.

Type:

float

reject_or_not#

Whether or not to reject the null hypothesis.

Type:

bool

truncated_intervals#

Intervals from which the selected model is obtained.

Type:

List[List[float]]

search_count#

Number of times the truncated intervals were searched.

Type:

int

detect_count#

Number of times that the same model as the observed model was obtained.

Type:

int

selected_model#

The model selected for the observed test statistic.

Type:

Any | None

mappings#

A dictionary that holds the model obtained at any point.

Type:

Dict[tuple[float], Any] | None

alpha: float#
detect_count: int#
inf_p: float#
mappings: dict[tuple[float, float], Any] | None#
p_value: float#
reject_or_not: bool#
search_count: int#
selected_model: Any | None#
stat: float#
sup_p: float#
truncated_intervals: list[list[float]]#
sicore.construct_projection_matrix(basis, verify=False)#

Construct projection matrix from basis.

Parameters:

  • basis (array-like) â€“ The basis of the k-dimensional subspace to be projected. The shape is (k, n).

  • verify (bool, optional) â€“ If True, check if the constructed matrix are valid or not, and raise exception. Set False for faster computation. Defaults to False.

Raises:

Exception â€“ When the constructed matrix does not satisfy the definition of a projection matrix.

Returns:

projection matrix

Return type:

np.ndarray

sicore.poly_lt_zero(poly_or_coef, tol=1e-10)#

Given a polynomial f(x), find the intervals of x where f(x) <= 0.

Parameters:

  • poly_or_coef (np.poly1d, array-like) â€“ np.poly1d object or coefficients of the polynomial e.g. [a, b, c] for f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c.

  • tol (float, optional) â€“ Tolerance error parameter. It is recommended to set a large value (about 1e-5) for high order polynomial (>= 3) or a polynomial with multiple root. Defaults to 1e-10.

Returns:

Intervals [[L1, U1], [L2, U2], â€¦] of x where f(x) <= 0.

Return type:

list

sicore.polytope_to_interval(a_vec, b_vec, A=None, b=None, c=None, tol=1e-10, use_sparse=False)#

Compute truncation intervals obtained from a polytope {xâ€™Ax+bâ€™x+c<=0} as a selection event.

Parameters:

  • a_vec (array-like) â€“ Vectors which satisfy observed_data = a_vec + b_vec * observed_test_static

  • b_vec (array-like) â€“ Vectors which satisfy observed_data = a_vec + b_vec * observed_test_static

  • A (array-like, optional) â€“ N`*`N matrix. Set None if A is unused. Defaults to None.

  • b (array-like, optional) â€“ N dimensional vector. Set None if b is unused. Defaults to None.

  • c (float, optional) â€“ Constant. Set None if c is unused. Defaults to None.

  • tol (float, optional) â€“ Tolerance error parameter. Defaults to 1e-10.

  • use_sparse (boolean, optional) â€“ Whether to use sparse array or not. Defaults to False.

Returns:

truncation intervals [[L1, U1], [L2, U2], â€¦].

Return type:

array-like

sicore.power(pvalues, alpha=0.05)#

Calculate true positive rate of p-values under alternative.

Parameters:

  • pvalues (array-like) â€“ List of p-values.

  • alpha (float, optional) â€“ Significance level.

Returns:

True positive rate.

Return type:

float

sicore.pvalues_hist(pvalues, bins=20, title=None, fname=None, figsize=(6, 4))#

Plot histogram of p-values.

Parameters:

  • pvalues (array-like) â€“ List of p-values.

  • bins (int, optional) â€“ The number of bins. Defaults to 20.

  • title (str, optional) â€“ Title of the figure. Defaults to None.

  • fname (str, optional) â€“ File name. If fname is given, the plotted figure will be saved as a file. Defaults to None.

  • figsize (tuple, optional) â€“ Size of the figure. Defaults to (6, 4).

sicore.pvalues_qqplot(pvalues, plot_pos=None, title=None, fname=None, figsize=(4, 4))#

Plot uniform Q-Q plot of p-values.

Parameters:

  • pvalues (array-like) â€“ List of p-values.

  • plot_pos (array-like, optional) â€“ Plotting positions. If None, default plotting positions will be used. Defaults to None.

  • title (str, optional) â€“ Title of the figure. Defaults to None.

  • fname (str, optional) â€“ File name. If fname is given, the plotted figure will be saved as a file. Defaults to None.

  • figsize (tuple, optional) â€“ Size of the figure. Defaults to (4, 4).
